intro: Aphanochilus incisus, commonly known as the narrow-leafed sedge, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to southern Africa. It typically grows in wetland or marshy habitats, where it thrives in moist, nutrient-rich soils. The plant has slender, grass-like leaves that are often slightly toothed or notched along the edges. Its flowers are small and clustered in spikelets, which are characteristic of the Cyperaceae family. Aphanochilus incisus plays an important ecological role in stabilizing wetland soils and providing habitat for various invertebrates.
